member.name: T:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.Exceptions.NamespaceDoc

summary.para: These are the namespace comments for SbsSW.SwiPlCs.Exceptions.
The namespace SbsSW.SwiPlCs.Exceptions provides the Exception classes to catch a prolog exception see SWI-Prolog Manual - 4.9 ISO compliant Exception handling
Prolog exceptions are mapped to C# exceptions using the subclass PlException of to represent the Prolog exception term.
All type-conversion functions of the interface raise Prolog-compliant exceptions, providing decent error-handling support at no extra work for the programmer.
For some commonly used exceptions, subclasses of PlException have been created to exploit both their constructors for easy creation of these exceptions as well as selective trapping in C#.
Currently, these are and .

member.todo: To throw an exception, create an instance of PlException and use throw() or cppThrow(). The latter refines the C# exception class according to the represented Prolog exception before calling throw().

member.name: T:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.Exceptions.PlLibException
member.summary: This exception is thrown if something in the interface went wrong.

summary.para: This class is the base class to catch exceptions thrown by prolog in C#.

member.name: T:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.Exceptions.PlTypeException
member.summary: A type error expresses that a term does not satisfy the expected basic Prolog type.
member.example: This sample demonstrate how to catch a PlTypeException in C# that is thrown somewhere int the prolog code.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.Exceptions.PlTypeException.#ctor(System.String,SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)
member.summary: Creates an ISO standard Prolog error term expressing the expected type and actual term that does not satisfy this type.

member.name: T:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.Exceptions.PlDomainException
member.summary: A domain exception expresses that a term satisfies the basic Prolog type expected, but is unacceptable to the restricted domain expected by some operation.
member.example: For example, the standard Prolog open/3 call expect an IO-Mode (read, write, append, ...). If an integer is provided, this is a type error, if an atom other than one of the defined IO-modes is provided it is a domain error.

summary.para: This class allows queries to prolog.
A query can be created by a string or by constructing compound terms see Constructors for details.
All resources an terms created by a query are reclaimed by . It is recommended to build a query in a scope.
There are four possible opportunities to query Prolog

item.description: To ask prolog for a proof. Return only true or false.
To get the first result of a goal

item.term: Construct a PlQuery object by a string.
Construct a PlQuery object by compound terms.
item.description: The most flexible and fast (runtime) way.

summary.para: For examples see and

remarks.para: The query will be opened by and will be closed if NextSolution() return false.

member.summary: Release all resources from the query

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlQuery.Free(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Discards the query, but does not delete any of the data created by the query if discardData is false. It just invalidate qid, allowing for a new PlQuery object in this context.
member.param: if true all bindings of the query are destroyed

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlQuery.#ctor(System.String)

overloads.para: With these constructors a Prolog query can be created but not opened. To get the results see
A Query can be created from a string or by a name and PlTermV. The later is a native way and available for compatibility.
If a Query is created from a string representing arbitrary prolog text the helper classes and comes into the game. In this case the most convenient way to get the results is to use or .

summary.para: With this constructor a query is created from a string.
Uppercase parameters are interpreted a variables but can't be nested in sub terms. If you need a variable in a nested term use . See the examples for details.

summary.para: The namespace SbsSW.SwiPlCs.Streams provides the delegates to redirect the read and write functions of the SWI-Prolog IO Streams.
When is called the *Sinput->functions.read is replaced by the .NET method 'Sread_function' and *Sinput->functions.write by 'Swrite_funktion'.
For further examples see the methods and

remarks.note: The reason for this is debugging.

summary.para: The online documentation home is here.
This namespace SbsSW.SwiPlCs provides an .NET interface to SWI-Prolog

Prolog variables are dynamically typed and all information is passed around using the C-interface type term_t witch is an int. In C#, term_t is embedded in the lightweight struct . Constructors and operator definitions provide flexible operations and integration with important C#-types (string, int and double).
The list below summarises the important classes / struct defined in the C# interface.

item.description: A static class represents the prolog engine.

example.para: Before going into a detailed description of the CSharp classes let me present a few examples illustrating the `feel' of the interface. The Assert class in the sample is from the test framework and has nothing to do with the interface. It shows only which return values are expected.
This very simple example shows the basic creation of a Prolog term and how a Prolog term is converted to C#-data:
This example shows how to make a simple call to prolog.
example.code: PlTerm l1 = new PlTerm("[a,b,c,d]"); Assert.IsTrue(PlQuery.PlCall("is_list", l1));
example.h4: Getting the solutions of a query
example.para: This example shows how to obtain all solutions of a prolog query.

takes the name of a predicate and the goal-argument vector as arguments. From this information it deduces the arity and locates the predicate. the member-function NextSolution() yields true if there was a solution and false otherwise. If the goal yielded a Prolog exception it is mapped into a C# exception.
There is an other constructor of which simplify the sample above.
An other way to get the results is to use to iterate over .
It is also possible to get all solutions in a list by . This could be used to work with LinQ to objects which is really nice. and for further samples.

member.name: T:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlType
member.summary: Obtain the type of a term, which should be a term returned by one of the other interface predicates or passed as an argument. The function returns the type of the Prolog term. The type identifiers are listed below.
member.remarks: see PL_term_type(term_t) in the SWI-Prolog Manual.

member.name: F:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlType.PlUnknown
member.summary: 0 - PL_UNKNOWN: Undefined

member.name: F:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlType.PlVariable
member.summary: 1 - PL_VARIABLE: An unbound variable. The value of term as such is a unique identifier for the variable.

member.name: F:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlType.PlAtom
member.summary: 2 - PL_ATOM: A Prolog atom.

member.name: F:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlType.PlInteger
member.summary: 3 - PL_INTEGER: A Prolog integer.

member.name: F:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlType.PlFloat
member.summary: 4 - PL_FLOAT: A Prolog floating point number.

member.name: F:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlType.PlString
member.summary: 5 - PL_STRING: A Prolog string.

member.name: F:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlType.PlTerm
member.summary: 6 - PL_TERM: A compound term. Note that a list is a compound term ./2.

summary.para: The PlTerm plays a central role in conversion and operating on Prolog data.
PlTerm implements to support ordering in queries if PlTerm is a List.
Creating a PlTerm can be done by the Constructors or by the following static methods:
PlVar(), PlTail(), PlCompound, PlString(), PlCodeList(), PlCharList() (see remarks)

item.description: Creates a new initialised term (holding a Prolog variable).
PlTail is for analysing and constructing lists.
Create compound terms. E.g. by parsing (as read/1) the given text.
Create a Prolog list of ASCII codes from a 0-terminated C-string.
Create a Prolog list of one-character atoms from a 0-terminated C-string.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.PlTail(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)

summary.para: PlTail is for analysing and constructing lists. It is called PlTail as enumeration-steps make the term-reference follow the `tail' of the list.

A PlTail is created by making a new term-reference pointing to the same object. As PlTail is used to enumerate or build a Prolog list, the initial list term-reference keeps pointing to the head of the list.

member.returns: A PlTerm for which is_list/1 succeed.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.PlCompound(System.String)

summary.para: These static methods creates a new compound .
For an example

member.summary: Create a term by parsing (as read/1) the text.
member.exception:
If the text is not valid Prolog syntax, a syntax error exception is raised.
Otherwise a new term-reference holding the parsed text is created.
member.param: The string representing the compound term parsed by read/1.

example.para: The example below creates the Prolog term hello(world).

member.param: The functor (name) of the compound term

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.PlCompound(System.String,SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)

summary.para: Create a compound term with the given name ant the arguments

member.param: The functor (name) of the compound term

overloads.para: A SWI-Prolog string represents a byte-string on the global stack. It's lifetime is the same as for compound terms and other data living on the global stack. Strings are not only a compound representation of text that is garbage-collected, but as they can contain 0-bytes, they can be used to contain arbitrary C-data structures.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.PlCodeList(System.String)
member.summary: Create a Prolog list of ASCII codes from a 0-terminated C-string.

summary.para: These static methods creates a new PlCharList TODO TODO .

member.summary: Create a Prolog list of one-character atoms from a C#-string.
member.remarks: Character lists are compliant to Prolog's atom_chars/2 predicate.
member.returns: A new PlTerm containing a prolog list of character

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.Append(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)
member.summary:
Appends element to the list and make the PlTail reference point to the new variable tail. If A is a variable, and this method is called on it using the argument "gnat", a list of the form [gnat|B] is created and the PlTail object now points to the new variable B.
This method returns TRUE if the unification succeeded and FALSE otherwise. No exceptions are generated.
member.param: The PlTerm to append on the list.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.Add(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)
member.summary: Appends an element to a list by creating a new one and copy all elements Note This is a slow version see my mail from Jan from 2007.11.06 14:44

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.AddList(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)
member.summary: Appends a list ( PlTail ) to a list by creating a new one and copy all elements

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.Close
member.summary: Unifies the term with [] and returns the result of the unification.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.NextValue
member.summary: return a PlTerm bound to the next element of the list PlTail and advance PlTail. Returns the element on success or a free PlTerm (Variable) if PlTail represents the empty list. If PlTail is neither a list nor the empty list, a PlTypeException (type_error) is thrown.
member.returns: The Next element in the list as a PlTerm which is a variable for the last element or an empty list

member.summary: Converts to a strongly typed ReadOnlyCollection of PlTerm objects that can be accessed by index
member.returns: A strongly typed ReadOnlyCollection of PlTerm objects

member.summary: Converts to a strongly typed Collection of strings that can be accessed by index

member.summary: Returns an enumerator that iterates through a collection.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.Next(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm@)
member.summary: Bind termRef to the next element of the list PlTail and advance PlTail. Returns TRUE on success and FALSE if PlTail represents the empty list. If PlTail is neither a list nor the empty list, a type_error is thrown.

summary.para: If PlTerm is a list the string is build by calling ToString() for each element in the list separated by ',' and put the brackets around '[' ']'.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.ToStringCanonical
member.summary:
Convert a PlTerm to a strin by write_canonical/1
This Method use and is slow.
member.returns: return the string of a PlTerm

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.Unify(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)
member.overloads:
This methods performs Prolog unification and returns true if successful and false otherwise. It is equal to the prolog =/2 operator.
See for an example.
This methods are introduced for clear separation between the destructive assignment in C# using = and prolog unification.
member.summary: Unify a PlTerm with a PlTerm

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.op_Explicit(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)~System.String
member.summary: Converts the Prolog argument into a string which implies Prolog atoms and strings are converted to the represented text or throw a PlTypeException.
member.remarks: Converts the Prolog argument using PL_get_chars() using the flags CVT_ALL|CVT_WRITE|BUF_RING, which implies Prolog atoms and strings are converted to the represented text or throw a PlTypeException. All other data is handed to write/1.
member.param: A PlTerm that can be converted to a string
member.exception: Is thrown if the operator is used on an uninitialized PlTerm

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.op_Explicit(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)~System.Int32
member.summary: Yields a int if the PlTerm is a Prolog integer or float that can be converted without loss to a int. Throws a PlTypeException exception otherwise
member.param: A PlTerm is a Prolog integer or float that can be converted without loss to a int.
member.exception: Throws a PlTypeException exception if is not a or a .
Is thrown if the operator is used on an uninitialized PlTerm

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.op_Explicit(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)~System.Double
member.summary: Yields the value as a C# double if PlTerm represents a Prolog integer or float. Throws a PlTypeException exception otherwise.
member.param: A PlTerm represents a Prolog integer or float
member.exception: Throws a PlTypeException exception if is not a or a .
Is thrown if the operator is used on an uninitialized PlTerm

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm.op_Equality(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm,SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)
member.overload: Compare the instance term1 with term2 and return the result according to the Prolog defined standard order of terms.
member.summary: Yields TRUE if the PlTerm is an atom or string representing the same text as the argument, FALSE if the conversion was successful, but the strings are not equal and an type_error exception if the conversion failed.

member.summary: summary

member.summary: test

member.name: T:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTermV
member.summary:
The class PlTermv represents an array of term-references.
This type is used to pass the arguments to a foreign defined predicate, construct compound terms (see and to create queries (see ). The only useful member function is the overloading of [], providing (0-based) access to the elements. Range checking is performed and raises a ArgumentOutOfRangeException exception.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTermV.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.overloads:
Create a PlTermV vector from the given PlTerm parameters
Create a new vector with PlTerm as elements
It can be created with elements
or
automatically for 1, 2 or 3 plTerms
member.summary: Create a vector of PlTerms with elements
member.param: The amount of PlTerms in the vector

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTermV.#ctor(SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTerm)
member.summary: Create a PlTermV from the given s.

member.summary: the first term_t reference of the array

member.name: P:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlTermV.Size
member.summary: Get the size of a PlTermV

member.summary: A zero based list
member.returns: The PlTerm for the given index
member.exception: Is thrown if the operator is used on an uninitialized PlTerm

member.name: T:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlFrame

summary.para: The class PlFrame provides an interface to discard unused term-references as well as rewinding unifications (data-backtracking). Reclaiming unused term-references is automatically performed after a call to a C#-defined predicate has finished and returns control to Prolog. In this scenario PlFrame is rarely of any use.

This class comes into play if the top level program is defined in C# and calls Prolog multiple times. Setting up arguments to a query requires term-references and using PlFrame is the only way to reclaim them.

member.example:
A typical use for PlFrame is the definition of C# methods that call Prolog and may be called repeatedly from C#. Consider the definition of assertWord(), adding a fact to word/1:
alternatively you can use
NOTE: in any case you have to destroy any query object used inside a PlFrame

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlFrame.Dispose
member.summary: Implement IDisposable.

remarks.para: Do not make this method virtual.
A derived class should not be able to override this method.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlFrame.#ctor
member.summary: Creating an instance of this class marks all term-references created afterwards to be valid only in the scope of this instance.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlFrame.Finalize
member.summary: Reclaims all term-references created after constructing the instance.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlFrame.Rewind
member.summary: Discards all term-references and global-stack data created as well as undoing all unifications after the instance was created.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlFrame.Free
member.summary: called by Dispose

member.name: T:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlEngine
member.summary: This static class represents the prolog engine.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlEngine.RegisterForeign(System.Delegate)

summary.para: Register a C-function to implement a Prolog predicate.
After this call returns successfully a predicate with name (a string) and arity arity (a C# int) is created in module module.
If module is NULL, the predicate is created in the module of the calling context or if no context is present in the module user.

remarks.para: Add a additional namespace by using SbsSW.SwiPlCs.Callback;

summary.para: Register a C# callback method

member.param: a delegate to a c# method
member.returns: true if registration succeed otherwise false

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlEngine.RegisterForeign(System.String,System.Delegate)
member.param: the name of a prolog module Using Modules

summary.para: Initialise SWI-Prolog
The write method of the output stream is redirected to before Initialize. The read method of the input stream just after Initialize.

remarks.para: A known bug: Initialize work *not* as expected if there are e.g. German umlauts in the parameters See marshalling in the sorce NativeMethods.cs

param.name: argv
param.para: For a complete parameter description see the SWI-Prolog reference manual section 2.4 Command-line options.
sample parameter: String[] param = { "-q", "-f", @"some\filename" }; At the first position a parameter "" is added in this method. PL_initialise

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlEngine.PlCleanup
member.summary: Try a clean up but it is buggy search the web for "possible regression from pl-5.4.7 to pl-5.6.27" to see reasons
member.remarks: Use this method only at the last call before run program ends

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlEngine.PlHalt
member.summary: Stops the PlEngine and the program
member.remarks: SWI-Prolog calls internally pl_cleanup and than exit(0)

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlEngine.PlThreadAttachEngine

summary.para: return : reference count of the engine
If an error occurs, -1 is returned.
If this Prolog is not compiled for multi-threading, -2 is returned.

member.returns: A reference count of the engine

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlEngine.PlThreadSelf
member.summary: Returns the integer Prolog identifier of the engine or -1 if the calling thread has no Prolog engine. This method is also provided in the single-threaded version of SWI-Prolog, where it returns -2.

member.name: M:SbsSW.SwiPlCs.PlEngine.PlThreadDestroyEngine
member.summary: Returns TRUE on success and FALSE if the calling thread has no engine or this Prolog does not support threads.
